description: This course explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures.
name: CORP RESP AND ETHICS

values.comments:
Corporate Responsibility and Ethics explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. The focus of LGST 210 includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures.

	Students described LGST 210 as a “great course” that was “interesting” and “eye-opening.” Multiple students reported that the class discussions were “thought provoking.” Overall, students enjoyed LGST 210.

	The majority of students agreed that Professor Strudler was “engaging,” “helpful,” and “humorous.” They appreciated the effort he made to “involve everyone in class discussions,” and usage of examples that “helped to make the material more interesting.” Additionally, students reported that Professor Strudler was “warm” and “approachable.” 

	This course comes recommended to majors and non-majors alike, especially “those interested in business ethics and morality.” However, one reported that the midterm “did not sufficiently evaluate course understanding.” Nevertheless, the majority of students enjoyed LGST 210.

LGST210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures.

The majority of students found this class to be “the best class at Penn” because they “learned many valuable lessons.” Students liked that they were “engaged in the class for the entire time” allowing them to “learn so much every class” although they “would have preferred more class time instead of the debates.” 

Overall, students found that Professor Rongione was “amazing.” Some students found that he “gets students to think and speak clearly and reasonably” and made students “question own beliefs in order to determine what kind of ethics” they had. Other students found he was “hilarious,”  “caring,” “engaging,” “accessible,” and “funny.” However, one student found that he “should share more personal experiences.” 

Some students found that there were some “hardships” in this class, because the “grading is pretty subjective and you don’t know your standing throughout the semester.” However, many students found that the “set up of the final paper reduces any stress for a timed final and lest you have a second pair of eyes to look over the final submission” because you can work with a partner. Most students found there was “not an overwhelming amount of work” and that the “readings are fascinating.” One student even noted that he wanted to keep his textbook “to read for pleasure in the future.” This course is sometimes listed as a Benjamin Franklin Seminar, and it has no prerequisites. It is open to all students in all schools.

Legal Studies 210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures.

Overall, this course was described as “interesting” and “inspiring.” However, many students complained that the course lacked a clear structure and focus. Specifically, students said the course was “based more on subjective personal opinions rather than objective hard facts.” Students generally thought they received little guidance and feedbacks on assignments, and many suggested the teaching staff should hold regular office hours. Some students felt the class was “too big to have successful discussions” that engaged all students. 

The majority of students described Professor Laufer as “knowledgeable”, “supportive,” and “inspiring.” Many also praised Professor Laufer for being kind and caring for the students. However, many students hoped Professor Laufer could be more accessible outside lectures and could give clearer and more concrete answers to questions and discussions. 

Students hoped the grade policies could be more transparent and fair because multiple students commented that they felt that grades were “arbitrary.” There are no prerequisites of this course.
